intro: Actinostemon imbricatus, commonly known as the mountain snowbell, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the mountainous regions of Central America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, white or pale blue flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves that are arranged alternately along the stem. Its flowering stems are often branched and bear clusters of small, fragrant flowers, making it a visually appealing addition to gardens. Actinostemon imbricatus thrives in well-drained soil and partial to full sunlight, preferring cooler climates.
